questions.question: Which force opposes motion between two surfaces in contact?

questions.answer: Sea water has higher density

questions.answer: Lactometer

questions.answer: Float inside liquid

questions.question: Pressure exerted depends on:
questions.answer: Force and area

questions.answer: To reduce pressure

questions.question: Why are dam walls broader at base?
questions.answer: Pressure is more at depth

questions.question: Blunt knife is difficult to cut because:
questions.answer: It has large area

questions.question: Why do passengers jerk forward when bus stops suddenly?
questions.answer: Due to inertia of motion

questions.question: Coin falls into glass when card is flicked because of:
questions.answer: Inertia of rest

questions.question: Which force changes shape of object?
questions.answer: Applied force

questions.question: Fluid includes:
questions.answer: Liquids and gases

questions.question: Pressure in fluid acts:
questions.answer: In all directions

questions.answer: Archimedes

Which quantity has no direction?
questions.answer: Pressure

questions.question: If area decreases and force constant, pressure will:
questions.answer: Increase

questions.question: Which force allows us to walk?
questions.answer: Friction

questions.question: Which statement is true?
questions.answer: Pressure increases with depth

questions.question: Which object will float?
questions.answer: Low density object

questions.question: Which quantity decides floating or sinking?
questions.answer: Density and buoyant force

questions.question: What is force? Explain with example.
questions.answer: Force is a push or pull that can change the shape, speed or direction of an object. For example, pushing a door to open it or pulling a cart are forces.

questions.question: What are contact forces?
questions.answer: Contact forces act only when two objects are in physical contact. Examples are muscular force and frictional force.

questions.question: What are non-contact forces?
questions.answer: Non-contact forces act without physical contact between objects. Examples include gravitational, magnetic and electrostatic forces.

questions.question: Explain frictional force.
questions.answer: Friction is a force that opposes motion between two surfaces in contact. It slows down moving objects and produces heat.

questions.question: What are balanced forces?
questions.answer: Balanced forces are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction. They do not change the state of motion of an object.

questions.question: What are unbalanced forces?
questions.answer: Unbalanced forces do not cancel each other. They cause change in speed, direction or shape of an object.

questions.question: Define inertia.
questions.answer: Inertia is the tendency of an object to resist change in its state of rest or motion. Greater mass means greater inertia.

questions.question: State Newton’s first law of motion.
questions.answer: An object remains at rest or in uniform motion unless acted upon by an unbalanced external force.

questions.question: What is pressure?
questions.answer: Pressure is the force acting per unit area. It increases when force increases or area of contact decreases.

questions.question: Why do sharp knives cut better?
questions.answer: Sharp knives have very small area of contact. This increases pressure for the same force, making cutting easier.

questions.question: Why do camels have broad feet?
questions.answer: Broad feet increase area of contact with sand. This reduces pressure and prevents sinking in soft sand.

questions.question: How does liquid pressure change with depth?
questions.answer: Liquid pressure increases with depth. Deeper points experience more pressure due to greater weight of liquid above.

questions.question: What is atmospheric pressure?
questions.answer: Atmospheric pressure is the pressure exerted by air on all objects. It decreases with increase in height.

questions.question: Why is it difficult to breathe on mountains?
questions.answer: At high altitudes, air pressure and oxygen level are low. This makes breathing difficult.

questions.question: What is buoyant force?
questions.answer: Buoyant force is the upward force exerted by a fluid on an object immersed in it. It helps objects to float.

questions.question: State Archimedes’ principle.
questions.answer: An object immersed in a fluid experiences an upward force equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by it.

questions.question: Why do ships float on water?
questions.answer: Ships displace large volume of water, producing enough buoyant force to balance their weight, so they float.

questions.question: Why is swimming easier in sea water?
questions.answer: Sea water has higher density, which provides more buoyant force. This helps the body float easily.

questions.question: What is density?
questions.answer: Density is mass per unit volume of a substance. It determines whether an object floats or sinks.

questions.question: Define relative density.
questions.answer: Relative density is the ratio of density of a substance to density of water. It has no unit.

questions.question: Why do heavy vehicles have more wheels?
questions.answer: More wheels increase area of contact with ground. This reduces pressure and prevents damage to roads.

questions.question: Why are dam walls thicker at the bottom?
questions.answer: Water pressure increases with depth. Thicker walls at bottom can withstand greater pressure.

questions.question: Explain pressure in gases.
questions.answer: Gas molecules move randomly and strike container walls. This creates pressure on the walls.

questions.question: What happens when buoyant force is less than weight?
questions.answer: If buoyant force is less than weight, the object sinks in the fluid.

questions.question: What happens when buoyant force equals weight?
questions.answer: The object remains suspended in the fluid without rising or sinking.

questions.question: What happens when buoyant force is greater than weight?
questions.answer: When buoyant force is greater than the weight of the object, the object floats on the surface of the liquid.

questions.question: Why does a balloon rise in air?
questions.answer: A balloon filled with lighter gas displaces heavier air. The buoyant force becomes greater than its weight, so it rises.

questions.question: Why do iron nails sink in water?
questions.answer: Iron has higher density than water. The buoyant force is less than the weight of the nail, so it sinks.

questions.question: What is thrust?
questions.answer: Thrust is the force acting perpendicular to a surface. It is responsible for producing pressure.

questions.question: How is pressure related to thrust and area?
questions.answer: Pressure equals thrust divided by area. If area decreases, pressure increases for the same thrust.

questions.question: Why do skiers use long and flat skis?
questions.answer: Long and flat skis increase contact area with snow. This reduces pressure and prevents sinking.

questions.question: Why does liquid flow from higher to lower level?
questions.answer: Liquid pressure is higher at greater depth. This pressure difference causes liquid to flow downward.

questions.question: What is fluid?
questions.answer: A fluid is a substance that can flow. Liquids and gases are considered fluids.

questions.question: How does pressure act in liquids?
questions.answer: Pressure in liquids acts equally in all directions. It increases with increase in depth.

questions.question: Why do divers feel more pressure under water?
questions.answer: As depth increases, more water is above the diver. This increases pressure on the body.

questions.question: What is density’s role in floating and sinking?
questions.answer: Objects with density less than liquid float, while objects with greater density sink in the liquid.

questions.question: What is lactometer used for?
questions.answer: A lactometer measures the purity of milk by checking its relative density.

questions.question: Why does a paper fall slower than a stone?
questions.answer: Air resistance is more on paper due to larger surface area. This slows down its fall.

questions.question: How does force change shape of objects?
questions.answer: When force is applied, it can stretch, compress or bend an object, changing its shape.

questions.question: What is net force?
questions.answer: Net force is the total force acting on an object after combining all individual forces.

questions.question: Why does a moving bus cause passengers to lean backward when it starts?
questions.answer: Due to inertia of rest, the body tends to remain at rest while the bus moves forward.

questions.question: Why does dust come out when carpet is beaten?
questions.answer: Dust has inertia of rest. When carpet moves, dust particles fall off due to inertia.

questions.question: What is inertia of direction?
questions.answer: It is the tendency of an object to continue moving in the same direction unless acted upon by force.

questions.question: Why do seat belts prevent injury?
questions.answer: Seat belts stop the body gradually, reducing sudden force due to inertia and preventing injury.

questions.question: How does friction help us?
questions.answer: Friction allows walking, writing and stopping of vehicles. Without friction, movement control is impossible.

questions.question: How can friction be reduced?
questions.answer: Friction can be reduced using lubricants, polishing surfaces or using wheels and ball bearings.

questions.question: Why is friction sometimes harmful?
questions.answer: Friction causes wear and tear of machine parts and produces unwanted heat, wasting energy.

questions.question: What is air resistance?
questions.answer: Air resistance is friction offered by air to moving objects. It slows down their motion.

questions.question: Why are parachutes used?
questions.answer: Parachutes increase air resistance and slow down falling, allowing safe landing.

questions.question: Give conclusion of Force and Pressure chapter.
questions.answer: Force causes changes in motion and shape, while pressure depends on force and area. These concepts explain many daily life phenomena.

questions.question: Why do buildings have wide foundations?
questions.answer: Wide foundations increase the area of contact with the ground. This reduces pressure and prevents buildings from sinking.

questions.question: Why is it easier to push a loaded cart on wheels?
questions.answer: Wheels reduce friction by changing sliding friction into rolling friction, making movement easier.

questions.question: What is rolling friction?
questions.answer: Rolling friction occurs when an object rolls over a surface. It is much less than sliding friction.

questions.question: How does friction depend on surface?
questions.answer: Rough surfaces produce more friction while smooth surfaces produce less friction.

questions.question: Why are lubricants used in machines?
questions.answer: Lubricants reduce friction between moving parts and prevent overheating and wear.

questions.question: What is terminal velocity?
questions.answer: It is the maximum constant speed reached when air resistance equals gravitational force during fall.

questions.question: Why do objects stop after some time on ground?
questions.answer: Friction and air resistance oppose motion and gradually reduce speed until object stops.

questions.question: What is pressure in solids?
questions.answer: Pressure in solids depends on applied force and contact area. Smaller area creates more pressure.

questions.question: How does pressure help in cutting tools?
questions.answer: Cutting tools have sharp edges with small area, producing high pressure for easy cutting.

questions.question: Why are nails pointed?
questions.answer: Pointed tips reduce contact area, increasing pressure and allowing nails to enter surfaces easily.

questions.question: Why do astronauts feel weightless in space?
questions.answer: In space, gravity is very weak and astronauts are in continuous free fall, causing weightlessness.

questions.question: What is free fall?
questions.answer: Free fall is motion of an object under gravity only, without any opposing forces.

questions.question: How does gravity affect pressure?
questions.answer: Gravity causes fluids to exert pressure due to their weight, increasing pressure with depth.

questions.question: What is thrust in fluids?
questions.answer: Thrust in fluids is force acting normally on surfaces due to fluid pressure.

questions.question: Why do balloons burst at high altitude?
questions.answer: Outside air pressure decreases with height, so air inside expands and bursts the balloon.

questions.question: How do submarines sink and float?
questions.answer: Submarines control buoyancy by filling or emptying water in tanks, changing overall density.

questions.question: Why is cork lighter than water?
questions.answer: Cork has lower density than water, so buoyant force is greater than its weight and it floats.

questions.question: Why do ships not sink though made of iron?
questions.answer: Ships are hollow and displace large water volume, giving enough buoyant force to float.

questions.question: What is specific gravity?
questions.answer: Specific gravity is ratio of density of substance to density of water and has no unit.

questions.question: Why do floating objects displace water?
questions.answer: Floating objects push water aside to create buoyant force equal to their weight.

questions.question: How does shape affect floating?
questions.answer: Hollow shapes displace more water and experience greater buoyant force, helping them float.

questions.question: Why does ice float on water?
questions.answer: Ice has lower density than water, so buoyant force is greater than its weight.

questions.question: Why is pressure same at same depth?
questions.answer: At equal depth, weight of liquid above is same, producing equal pressure in all directions.

questions.question: What happens to pressure when force increases?
questions.answer: When force increases and area remains constant, pressure also increases.

questions.question: How does area affect pressure?
questions.answer: Pressure decreases when area increases and increases when area decreases, if force is constant.

questions.question: Why is it dangerous to walk on thin ice?
questions.answer: Small contact area produces high pressure, which can break the ice and cause sinking.

questions.question: Why are broad tyres used in tractors?
questions.answer: Broad tyres increase contact area and reduce pressure on soft soil, preventing sinking.

questions.question: Why does air pressure affect boiling point?
questions.answer: Lower atmospheric pressure reduces boiling point, so water boils at lower temperature on mountains.

questions.question: What is Pascal’s principle?
questions.answer: Pressure applied to confined fluid is transmitted equally in all directions.

questions.question: Give one application of Pascal’s principle.
questions.answer: Hydraulic brakes in vehicles work on Pascal’s principle to transmit pressure effectively.

questions.question: Why does friction produce heat?
questions.answer: When surfaces rub, kinetic energy converts into heat due to friction.

questions.question: How does air resistance help parachutists?
questions.answer: Air resistance slows their fall, allowing safe landing without injury.

questions.question: Why are helmets important for riders?
questions.answer: Helmets increase time of impact and reduce force on head, preventing serious injury.

questions.question: What is pressure cooker principle?
questions.answer: Increased pressure raises boiling point of water, cooking food faster.

questions.question: Why do we feel lighter in water?
questions.answer: Buoyant force acts upward and reduces apparent weight of body in water.

questions.question: What is apparent weight?
questions.answer: Apparent weight is reduced weight felt in fluid due to upward buoyant force.

questions.question: Why do suction cups stick to surfaces?
questions.answer: Air is removed creating low pressure inside, and outside air pressure holds it tight.

questions.question: Why do storm winds cause damage?
questions.answer: Strong winds apply large unbalanced forces that can uproot trees and damage structures.

questions.question: How does gravity affect motion?
questions.answer: Gravity pulls objects toward Earth and accelerates falling objects downward.

questions.question: Why does a ball stop after rolling?
questions.answer: Friction and air resistance gradually reduce its speed until it stops.

questions.question: What is equilibrium of forces?
questions.answer: When net force on an object is zero, forces are in equilibrium and motion does not change.

questions.question: Why do objects move faster on smooth surfaces?
questions.answer: Smooth surfaces have less friction, so less force opposes motion.

questions.question: Why are ball bearings used in machines?
questions.answer: They convert sliding friction into rolling friction, reducing energy loss.

questions.question: How does force change direction of motion?
questions.answer: Applied force can deflect object from its path, changing direction of movement.

questions.question: What is net pressure?
questions.answer: Net pressure is total pressure acting on a surface after considering all forces.

questions.question: Why are sharp heels harmful for floors?
questions.answer: Small contact area produces very high pressure which damages floor surface.

questions.question: Why do heavy objects need more force to move?
questions.answer: Heavier objects have greater inertia, so more force is required to change motion.

questions.question: What is pressure in gases?
questions.answer: Gas pressure is due to collision of fast moving molecules with container walls.

questions.question: Why do footballs become flat in cold weather?
questions.answer: Gas contracts in cold, reducing internal pressure and making ball appear flat.

questions.question: Give overall conclusion of Force and Pressure chapter.
questions.answer: Force changes motion and shape, while pressure depends on force and area. Buoyancy and density explain floating and sinking.
